messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] Florida
messages.msgSnippet: One of the best places to see them is in Volusia county, a little south and west of Daytona. It s called Blue Springs State Park, I think the town is called
messages.messageBody:
One of the best places to see them is in Volusia county, a little south and
west of Daytona. It's called Blue Springs State Park, I think the town is
called Deland. I think it's only about a half hour to 45 min. away from
Daytona.
Hope our cold snap holds for you so you'll be able to see them. The manatee
exhibit at Sea World is nice too. It's very doom and gloomy though. Sea
World is awesome, it's the only park we buy passes to, unfortunately they
expired on the first of the year or I'd meet you there :)
Are you going to Daytona to see the race track?
Denese

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] Florida
messages.msgSnippet: ... Traffic in Orlando is a nightmare. Not much to see in the city itself. There are a couple of cool things in the area of the attractions to see that are not
messages.messageBody:
>
>
> We will be in Florida in a few weeks and will be visiting Orlando,
Traffic in Orlando is a nightmare. Not much to see in the city itself. There
are a couple of cool things in the area of the attractions to see that are
not very heavily advertised. There is a place called world of orchids if
your interested in that type of thing, they have a pretty good size lab
where they grow the seedlings, very interesting.
Be careful if you are staying near Disney, people do prey on tourists, just
be aware.

the Everglades
Never been there. I hear there are places in Miami where one would do well
not to get off the highway.
My nephew recently returned from a camping and airboat tour of the
Everglades and he loved it. Bring mosquito repelent., he was completely
covered in bites :)

If it is cold when you come a stop by one of our springs would be really
cool if you are interested in manatees.
Last winter we saw over a hundred in one place. It is a really neat
experience because all you ever hear is how they are always turning up
slaughtered by boats.

and the Space place.

Last time we went there were armed soilders with automatic weapons
everywhere you looked. It was kind of unsettling to the little ones.
Security is very tight, most likely everything you bring will be thoroughly
searched.
And it costs about sixty dollars to have hotdogs for lunch there. Don't go
hungry. Otherwise it is awesome beyond belief, you won't believe the size of
the rockets. The memorial they have to fallen astronauts is very nice.
Don't miss Ron Jon if you get the chance, it is very close to KSC. Cocoa
beach is a nice quiet little town and they have a nice restaruant on the
pier there.

Getting into Universal cheeply? I don't know, haven't figured that one out
yet, meet some people who work there and borrow their uniforms. It's
expensive. I have no idea how people can afford to come here and see all the
attractions.
Hope you have a great trip.
Denese

Any tips on what to see, dangers to avoid, ways to get into Universal Studio
cheaply will be
> appreciated.
>
> Shyrley

messages.subject: BOOKS
messages.msgSnippet: Hi All, I had a conversation with our librarian yesterday. She wanted to know what books I felt they should have available for homeschoolers, and a list of
messages.messageBody:
Hi All,

I had a conversation with our librarian yesterday. She wanted to know
what books I felt they should have available for homeschoolers, and a
list of books about homeschoolers, especially fiction.

So my question is, in three parts:
* what reference books are "must haves" for the library
* what books about homeschoolers
* what books - fiction - with homeschoolers in them.

Thanks much!

peace,
Susan

"Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can
change the world; indeed, it is the only thing that ever has."
- Margaret Mead

"All we are saying is give peace a chance."
- John Lennon

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] Florida
messages.msgSnippet: I have to say.. we were down there last November,  stayed first in Cocoa Beach area, visited Space Camp, a friend of a friend is the nurse there.  Got a tour,
messages.messageBody:
I have to say..
we were down there last November, stayed first in Cocoa Beach area, visited Space Camp, a friend of a friend is the nurse there. Got a tour, we all loved it and almost got to see the shuttle take off but it was cloudy so it got called off. So we stayed longer at Animal Kingdom,

Those shuttles are the most tempramental things. I always feel bad for people who come just to see them.It's worse since last September of course. They don't even announce the time of the launch until the day before.The absolute best place to see them is the beach, at night. We lived a block from Cocoa Beach where we could see the rockets on the pads, it was so cool.

Florida was a dream in November,, we loved it, everything was pretty slow, Disneyworld, and everything, but the weather was awesome, walking down the walk way in front of Cinderalla's castle I was just sighing saying this is perfect.. 75-80 degrees, we didn't have to wait in lines for anything and we stayed at a Holiday Inn and Suites in a 3 br suite for around $90 a night, the week was great.

Then, in May we were down to Key Biscayne for a long weekend, Oh my gosh, I about died whenever I went outside, too hot for me.. If I was by the water, I was OK. Other wise, forget it. Sweated like a pig.
I don't think I fit in with that group of people. Like I told my dh, "I don't think my Winstar would fit in with these vehicles!!" I got some pretty odd looks as I was bringing some groceries and wine in from the grocery store!! <gg> The Ritz and me,....hmmm.. not quite in sync.
We won the trip, so it was free, I would never stay there again. Beautiful but soooo.. stuffy. If anyone wants to hear about our stay there, which was quite hilarious, let me know.

Love to hear funny stories about stuffy people:)
You think May is hot, try August. It's practically unbearable. I can't believe people come here then.

I would love to go down there, to FL, again, right now!

Such enthusiasm! Come on down!

The kids didn't get to go to Sea World, My husband and I did in May, we got to swim with the dolphins, ohhh, I wanted to bring one home.

I haven't had the chance to do that, man, you're lucky. We do get to see dolphins all the time, in the wild, whenever we go fishing or to the beach (even just driving by sometimes) I love them too:)

Denese




I'll stop now...

Kelli


Denese Kolb <DCOLB@...> wrote: I don't know what I'd do with the weather like you have in FL. I'd be one burned out camper, I get sooo energized by sunlight. Its almost intoxicating to me!!
Kelli, the penguin

Kelli,
You'ld be feeling drunk a lot:)
When it is October and still over 89 degrees outside, it does get old. None of my kids have ever seen snow and I would love for them to be able to.However, I have been to Niagra Falls in November and I know what cold is, so I am reluctant.
Enjoy your snow.
Denese


Yes but it doesnt go down in the 30s and stay there for days on end, at
lease not what I have heard about the orlando area. I want to be within an
hour of Sea World! Where are you at?
Heidi

Well, you have to put that into perspective. It is usually so steamy and hot here, that when it does get into the 30's, (which it does, occasionally) it is extremely cold to us. Even the 50's are cold to native or naturalized Floridaians. I am about an hour south of Sea World,(love it there, we have anual passes) on the Space Coast. Florida is great, come on down, lots of homeschoolers and unschoolers too:)
Denese

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] Florida
messages.msgSnippet: I have to say.. we were down there last November,  stayed first in Cocoa Beach area, visited Space Camp, a friend of a friend is the nurse there.  Got a tour,
messages.messageBody:
I have to say..
we were down there last November, stayed first in Cocoa Beach area, visited Space Camp, a friend of a friend is the nurse there. Got a tour, we all loved it and almost got to see the shuttle take off but it was cloudy so it got called off. So we stayed longer at Animal Kingdom,

Florida was a dream in November,, we loved it, everything was pretty slow, Disneyworld, and everything, but the weather was awesome, walking down the walk way in front of Cinderalla's castle I was just sighing saying this is perfect.. 75-80 degrees, we didn't have to wait in lines for anything and we stayed at a Holiday Inn and Suites in a 3 br suite for around $90 a night, the week was great.

Then, in May we were down to Key Biscayne for a long weekend, Oh my gosh, I about died whenever I went outside, too hot for me.. If I was by the water, I was OK. Other wise, forget it. Sweated like a pig.
I don't think I fit in with that group of people. Like I told my dh, "I don't think my Winstar would fit in with these vehicles!!" I got some pretty odd looks as I was bringing some groceries and wine in from the grocery store!! <gg> The Ritz and me,....hmmm.. not quite in sync.
We won the trip, so it was free, I would never stay there again. Beautiful but soooo.. stuffy. If anyone wants to hear about our stay there, which was quite hilarious, let me know.

I would love to go down there, to FL, again, right now!
The kids didn't get to go to Sea World, My husband and I did in May, we got to swim with the dolphins, ohhh, I wanted to bring one home.

I'll stop now...

Kelli


Denese Kolb <DCOLB@...> wrote: I don't know what I'd do with the weather like you have in FL. I'd be one burned out camper, I get sooo energized by sunlight. Its almost intoxicating to me!!
Kelli, the penguin

Kelli,
You'ld be feeling drunk a lot:)
When it is October and still over 89 degrees outside, it does get old. None of my kids have ever seen snow and I would love for them to be able to.However, I have been to Niagra Falls in November and I know what cold is, so I am reluctant.
Enjoy your snow.
Denese


Yes but it doesnt go down in the 30s and stay there for days on end, at
lease not what I have heard about the orlando area. I want to be within an
hour of Sea World! Where are you at?
Heidi

Well, you have to put that into perspective. It is usually so steamy and hot here, that when it does get into the 30's, (which it does, occasionally) it is extremely cold to us. Even the 50's are cold to native or naturalized Floridaians. I am about an hour south of Sea World,(love it there, we have anual passes) on the Space Coast. Florida is great, come on down, lots of homeschoolers and unschoolers too:)
Denese

messages.msgSnippet: I d say perspective,,,its a balmy 34 this morning and I was thinking earlier,  ohh, I have to get outside and enjoy the warm weather!    All my snow is
messages.messageBody:
I'd say perspective,,,its a balmy 34 this morning and I was thinking earlier, ohh, I have to get outside and enjoy the warm weather! All my snow is melting, the kids were all grumpy yesterday because they were trying to cross country ski and the snow was going, going.
Oh well, more will come soon I'm sure, I don't know what I'd do with the weather like you have in FL. I'd be one burned out camper, I get sooo energized by sunlight. Its almost intoxicating to me!!
Kelli, the penguin
